qas.question: What is the term for the gait of an insect characterized by walking in alternating triangles?
What larval adaptation is common to underwater insects?
What species of insect has the capability to walk on the surface of water?
What do crickets do in order to attract or repel a mate?
What variation of beetle in the Coleoptera order communicate by way of light?
Insects move by walking, flying, and what else?
Which insects walk, fly, and swim?
Insects walk the ground in alternating what?
Insects walking in an alternating triangle is called a what?
What can insects do with each other in a variety of ways?

context: <a6_0>Adult<a6_0/> insects typically move about by walking, flying, or sometimes <a5_0>swimming<a5_0/> (see below, Locomotion). As it allows for rapid yet stable movement, many insects adopt a <a0_0><a8_0>tripedal<a0_0/> gait<a8_0/> in which they walk with their legs touching the ground in alternating <a7_0>triangles<a7_0/>. Insects are the only invertebrates to have evolved flight. Many insects spend at least part of their lives under water, with larval adaptations that include <a1_0>gills<a1_0/>, and some adult insects are aquatic and have adaptations for swimming. Some species, such as <a2_0>water striders<a2_0/>, are capable of walking on the surface of water. Insects are mostly solitary, but some, such as certain bees, ants and termites, are social and live in large, well-organized colonies. Some insects, such as earwigs, show maternal care, guarding their eggs and young. Insects can <a9_0>communicate<a9_0/> with each other in a variety of ways. Male moths can sense the pheromones of female moths over great distances. Other species communicate with sounds: crickets <a3_0>stridulate<a3_0/>, or rub their wings together, to attract a mate and repel other males. <a4_0>Lampyridae<a4_0/> in the beetle order Coleoptera communicate with light.
